title: 106_hr2773
content: The Act may be cited as the "Wekiva Wild and Scenic River Act of 2000". The Congress finds that the Wekiva River and its tributaries are eligible for inclusion in the national wild and scenic rivers system. Florida has shown commitment to protecting these rivers through various measures. The Florida counties of Lake, Seminole, and Orange have demonstrated commitment to protect rivers and streams through land use plans and regulations. Public, state, and local agency support exists for designating these rivers as part of the national wild and scenic rivers system. The Wekiva River, Rock Springs Run, and Black Water Creek are held in public ownership or conservation. The Wekiva River, Rock Springs Run, and Black Water Creek are protected in public ownership or conservation easements in Florida. The Wekiva River and its tributaries in Florida are designated as components of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System. The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act is amended to include the Wekiva River, Wekiwa Springs Run, Rock Springs Run, and Black Water Creek in Florida, totaling 41.6 miles to be administered by the Secretary of the Interior. The Wekiva River and Wekiwa Springs Run will be classified as a wild river in different segments. The Wekiva River in Florida, totaling 41.6 miles, will be classified as a recreational river and a wild river in different segments. The Wekiwa Springs Run and Rock Springs Run will also be included in the classification administered by the Secretary of the Interior. The Wekiva River in Florida will be classified as a recreational river and a wild river in different segments, including Rock Springs Run and Black Water Creek. The Wekiva River in Florida is classified into different segments: a scenic river, a wild river, and a recreational river. The segments range from approximately 4.4 miles to 0.9 miles in length, with varying classifications based on specific locations along the river. The Wekiva River in Florida is classified into different segments: a scenic river, a wild river, and a recreational river. The segments range from approximately 4.7 miles to 0.6 miles in length, with varying classifications based on specific locations along the river. SEC. 4. SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS APPLICABLE TO WEKIVA RIVER AND TRIBUTARIES. In this section, definitions are provided for terms related to the Wekiva River system, including the Wekiva River, Wekiwa Springs Run, Rock Springs Run, and Black Water Creek in Florida. The Committee refers to the Wekiva River System Advisory Management Committee, and the Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Interior. Additionally, the comprehensive management plan is defined as the plan to be developed for the Wekiva River system. The Secretary will offer cooperative agreements for the long-term protection of the Wekiva River system with the State of Florida and local jurisdictions, excluding National Park Service administration. The Secretary will review compliance with the comprehensive management plan for the Wekiva River system biennially and report any deviations to the House Committee on Resources and the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources to prevent any diminution of the designated values. The Secretary may provide technical assistance, staff support, and funding for the development and implementation of the comprehensive management plan, with limitations on funding for land acquisition, facility development, or operations. SEC. 5. WEKIVA RIVER SYSTEM ADVISORY MANAGEMENT COMMITTEE. The Secretary will establish the Wekiva River System Advisory Management Committee, composed of representatives from various agencies and organizations to assist in developing a comprehensive management plan for the Wekiva River system. The Wekiva River System Advisory Management Committee includes representatives from various agencies and organizations such as the Division of Forestry, Florida Audubon Society, Friends of the Wekiva, and others. Additional members can be added by request and appointment is made by the Secretary. The Wekiva River System Advisory Management Committee consists of representatives appointed by different agencies and organizations. The Committee's role is to assist in developing a comprehensive management plan for the Wekiva River system and provide advice to the Secretary, without regulatory authority. The Committee has an advisory role without regulatory or land acquisition authority. Each member agency, division, or organization has one vote and must provide one member and one alternate. Committee decisions require three-fourths consent of all voting members, with additional procedures to be developed as part of the management plan. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums may be appropriated to carry out this Act and paragraph (161) of section 3(a) of the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act.
